item.title: Problem Solving ‚Äì Thinking Clearly Under Interview Constraints
item.description:
Introduction to Problem Solving

1. Why This Section Exists

Most coding interviews do not test whether you can recall algorithms or data structures from memory.

They test whether you can:

  • understand an unfamiliar problem,
  • reason about constraints,
  • choose an appropriate approach,
  • and write correct, explainable code under time pressure.

This section exists to train that exact skill ‚Äî the ability to think clearly when the solution is not immediately obvious.

item.title: Problem Solving Core Patterns ‚Äì Recognizing the Shape of Problems
item.description:
Introduction to Problem Solving Core Patterns

1. Why Patterns Matter in Problem Solving

In interviews, most problems are not new.

They are variations of familiar ideas, disguised with different wording, constraints, or data.

Problem solving patterns exist to help you:

  • recognize the shape of a problem quickly,
  • avoid reinventing solutions from scratch,
  • and move from confusion to clarity faster.

Patterns are not shortcuts for thinking ‚Äî
they are accelerators for structured thinking.

item.title: Git Commands ‚Äì Practical Reference Guide
item.description:
Overview

This page is a personal Git reference guide ‚Äî a practical, no-fluff collection of commonly used Git commands and workflows.

It is intentionally reference-oriented, not a full tutorial. The goal is:

  • Quick recall during daily work
  • Safe recovery from common mistakes
  • Clear mental models for branching, rebasing, and cleanup

A structured Git tutorial will follow later.

1. Core Git Commands (Daily Use)

Command Description
git –version Displays the installed Git version
git init Initializes a new Git repository (.git directory is created)
git status Shows current repository state (staged, unstaged, untracked files)
git config –global user.name “Your Name” Sets global Git username
git config –global user.email “your@email.com” Sets global Git email
git add Adds specific file(s) to the staging area
git add . / git add –all Stages all modified and new files
git commit -m “message” Creates a commit with a message
git commit Opens editor to write a detailed commit message
git log Shows commit history (most recent first)
git log –oneline Compact one-line commit history
git log –patch Shows commit history along with code diffs

2. Staging & Unstaging Changes

Unstage Files (Keep Changes)

Command Use Case
git reset HEAD Unstages a specific file
git reset HEAD . Unstages all staged files
git rm –cached Removes file from Git tracking but keeps it locally

üí° These commands do not delete code, only move files out of staging.

item.title: Design Patterns ‚Äì Introduction: From Principles to Practice
item.description:
1. Why Design Patterns Exist

As software systems grow, the same design problems appear again and again:

  • object creation becomes complex
  • behavior varies based on context
  • systems become tightly coupled
  • changes ripple through unrelated code

Design patterns exist because these problems are recurring.

Design patterns are named solutions to common design problems.

They are not libraries.
They are not frameworks.
They are not rules.

They are communication tools and proven structures.

item.title: History Of Programming
item.description:
1. The Origin of Programming

Early Beginnings:

The journey of programming begins in the 19th century with visionary minds like Charles Babbage and Ada Lovelace. Babbage, often called the “father of the computer,” conceptualized the Analytical Engine, a mechanical general-purpose computer. Ada Lovelace, a mathematician and writer, is credited with creating the first algorithm intended to be processed by a machine, making her the world’s first programmer. Her notes on the Analytical Engine include what is recognized today as the first algorithm designed for implementation on a computer.

The Two Pointers pattern uses two indices (pointers) that move through a data structure in a coordinated way.

item.title: Creational Design Patterns ‚Äì Managing Object Creation
item.description:
1. Why Object Creation Is Not as Simple as new

At first glance, object creation looks trivial:

Employee emp = new Employee(...);

So why do we need design patterns for this?

Because in real systems, object creation is rarely just about creating an object.

It often involves:

  • deciding which concrete type to create
  • enforcing construction rules
  • handling optional or complex configuration
  • ensuring consistency across the system
  • preventing invalid or incomplete objects
  • isolating clients from implementation details

As systems grow, object creation logic tends to spread, duplicate, and hard-code assumptions.

item.title: SRP ‚Äì Basics and Initial Refactoring
item.description:
1. What is the Single Responsibility Principle (SRP)?

Definition: A class (or module, or method) should have only one reason to change.

The Single Responsibility Principle helps developers write cleaner, more testable, and easier-to-maintain code by separating concerns. Also, avoids common anti-patterns seen in interviews and production systems

It is the first and arguably the most foundational principle in the SOLID family. SRP emphasizes that each software unit (class, method, service, etc.) should be responsible for only one thing ‚Äî and therefore, should change only when that responsibility changes.

item.title: Keep It Simple, Stupid (KISS) - Keeping code simple and maintainable
item.description:
1. What is the KISS Principle?

The KISS principle stands for ‚ÄúKeep It Simple, Stupid‚Äù ‚Äî a reminder that software systems work best when they are kept simple and straightforward.

‚úÖ Simplicity is the key to readability, maintainability, and performance.

Over-engineering and overly complex solutions often lead to:

  • Fragile code
  • Hidden bugs
  • Difficult-to-onboard teams

2. Why is KISS Important?

  • Enhances Readability: Simple code is easier to understand and debug.
  • Reduces Bugs: Less complexity means fewer chances for things to go wrong.
  • Improves Collaboration: Clean code helps other developers quickly grasp the logic.
  • Speeds Up Development: Simple, modular code is faster to build and deploy.
  • Boosts Performance: Avoiding unnecessary logic results in leaner execution.

3. Violating KISS

üî¥ Example: Overcomplicated Code with Nested Conditions

class OrderProcessor {
    public void processOrder(Order order) {
        if (order != null) {
            if (order.isValid()) {
                if (order.getPayment().isAuthorized()) {
                    if (order.getCustomer().isActive()) {
                        if (order.getShipment().isReady()) {
                            // Process order
                        }
                    }
                }
            }
        }
    }
}

‚ùå What‚Äôs Wrong?

  • Too much nesting makes logic hard to follow.
  • Adding or modifying conditions becomes painful.
  • No separation of concerns.

‚Äã4. Applying KISS

‚úÖ Refactored Code Following KISS Principle

class OrderProcessor {
    public void processOrder(Order order) {
        if (!isOrderProcessable(order)) return;
        // Process order
    }

    private boolean isOrderProcessable(Order order) {
        return order !=null
            && order.isValid()
            && order.getPayment().isAuthorized()
            && order.getCustomer().isActive()
            && order.getShipment().isReady();
    }
}

‚úÖ Benefits:

  • Flat structure makes intent clear.
  • Easy to test and maintain.
  • Logic is encapsulated for reuse and clarity.

‚Äã5. How to Enforce KISS in Codebase?

  1. Avoid Over-Engineering ‚Äì Implement only necessary features instead of adding complexity for future use cases.
  2. Refactor Code ‚Äì Break down large functions into smaller, meaningful methods.
  3. Use Descriptive Naming ‚Äì Meaningful variable and method names enhance code clarity.
  4. Leverage Built-in Features ‚Äì Use standard libraries instead of writing unnecessary custom logic.
  5. Keep Functions Short & Focused ‚Äì Each method should do one thing well.
  6. Prefer Composition Over Inheritance - Keep behaviors modular and explicit.

Conclusion

The KISS principle is not about avoiding complexity altogether, but about managing complexity wisely. When code is simple, it becomes easier to test, scale, and collaborate on.

item.title: OCP ‚Äì Saving Data to Different Destinations
item.description:
1. What is the Open/Closed Principle (OCP)?

Definition: Software entities (classes, modules, functions, etc.) should be open for extension, but closed for modification.

The Open/Closed Principle ensures that you can add new functionality without changing existing code ‚Äî minimizing the risk of breaking something that already works.

This principle is key for:

  • ‚úÖ maintainability
  • ‚úÖ Minimizing regression bugs
  • ‚úÖ Scalable system architecture
  • ‚úÖ Supporting team parallelism in large projects

2. Design Problem: Saving Employee Data to Different Destinations

In the SRP chapter, we split responsibilities into clean collaborators (Employee, EmployeeFormatter, EmployeeFileSaver, EmployeeService).
In this OCP chapter, we build on that design and focus on how to add new saving options without editing the existing service.

item.title: You Ain't Gonna Need It (YAGNI) - Avoiding unnecessary features
item.description:
1. What is the YAGNI Principle?

YAGNI stands for ‚ÄúYou Aren‚Äôt Gonna Need It‚Äù. It‚Äôs a design and development philosophy that encourages you to only build what is required right now, not what you think might be needed in the future.

‚úÖ Focus on current requirements. Avoid speculative features.

This principle comes from Extreme Programming (XP) and aligns closely with Agile practices.

2. Why is YAGNI Important?

  • ‚úÖ Avoids Wasted Effort
    Building unused features consumes time and resources.

item.description:

The Law of Demeter (LoD) ‚Äî also known as the Principle of Least Knowledge ‚Äî states that:

‚ÄúA class should only talk to its immediate friends and not to strangers.‚Äù

In simpler terms: avoid chaining too many method calls across different objects. Each object should delegate work, not dig into the internal structure of others.

item.description:
1. What Is the Singleton Pattern?

The Singleton Pattern ensures that:

A class has exactly one instance and provides a global access point to it.

In other words:

  • Only one object of the class can ever exist
  • That object is shared across the application

The Singleton pattern is one of the most frequently discussed ‚Äî and misused ‚Äî design patterns in Java interviews.

This pattern belongs to the Creational Design Patterns family because it controls object creation.

item.title: DIP ‚Äì Decoupling Business Logic from Infrastructure
item.description:
1. What Is the Dependency Inversion Principle (DIP)?

High-level modules should not depend on low-level modules.
Both should depend on abstractions.

In simple terms:

Business logic should not depend on technical details.
Technical details should depend on business abstractions.

This principle is often misunderstood because it is frequently confused with Dependency Injection (DI).

item.title: 3Sum
item.description:
LeetCode Problem: 3Sum

1. Problem Statement

Given an integer array nums, return all the unique triplets [nums[i], nums[j], nums[k]] such that:

  • i, j, and k are distinct indices
  • nums[i] + nums[j] + nums[k] == 0

The solution set must not contain duplicate triplets.

Return the answer in any order.

2. Clarifying Questions (Interview Thinking)

Before coding, confirm:

  • Do we return indices or values? ‚Üí Values (triplets)
  • Should triplets be unique? ‚Üí Yes
  • Can the input contain duplicates? ‚Üí Yes
  • Can the array be modified? ‚Üí Yes (sorting allowed)
  • Does output order matter? ‚Üí No

3. Constraints & Edge Cases

  • nums.length < 3 ‚Üí return empty list
  • All zeros (e.g. [0,0,0,0]) ‚Üí only one triplet [0,0,0]
  • Multiple duplicates ‚Üí must be handled carefully
  • Large input ‚Üí brute force is too slow

4. Brute Force Idea

Try all triplets using three nested loops and store results in a set.

item.title: Container With Most Water
item.description:
LeetCode Problem: Container With Most Water

1. Problem Statement

You are given an integer array height where height[i] represents the height of a vertical line at index i.

Choose two lines that, together with the x-axis, form a container that holds the most water.

Return the maximum amount of water a container can store.

2. Clarifying Questions (Interview Thinking)

Before coding, confirm:

  • Are indices required or only the maximum area? ‚Üí Maximum area
  • Can heights be zero? ‚Üí Yes
  • Can we reorder the array? ‚Üí No
  • Any constraints on width? ‚Üí Width is right - left

3. Constraints & Edge Cases

  • height.length < 2 ‚Üí no container (typically not given by constraints)
  • All equal heights ‚Üí widest pair is best
  • Contains zeros ‚Üí area can be zero for some pairs
  • Large values ‚Üí compute area using int (fits LeetCode constraints)

4. Brute Force Idea

Check all pairs (i, j) and compute area.

item.title: Longest Repeating Character Replacement
item.description:
LeetCode Problem: Longest Repeating Character Replacement

1. Problem Statement

You are given a string s and an integer k.

You can replace at most k characters in the string so that the resulting substring contains only one repeating character.

Return the length of the longest possible substring after performing at most k replacements.

2. Clarifying Questions (Interview Thinking)

Before coding, confirm:

  • Is the substring required to be contiguous? ‚Üí Yes
  • Can we replace characters arbitrarily? ‚Üí Yes, up to k
  • Do we return the substring or its length? ‚Üí Length
  • Are characters uppercase only? ‚Üí Yes (A‚ÄìZ)

3. Constraints & Edge Cases

  • Empty string ‚Üí return 0
  • k = 0 ‚Üí longest block of identical characters
  • k >= s.length() ‚Üí entire string can be made uniform
  • Large input ‚Üí must be linear time

4. Brute Force Idea

Try all substrings and compute how many replacements are needed.
